Hopkins News-Letter

Patrick Henry!

Liberty
H AT

But the man who is particular about style will be
just as insistant as Patrick Henry about getting
the Liberty, — it's a hat
that stands for correctness in style and the utmost in value.

Hilarity and self-satisfaction, however, are not the only elements
to enter into the mind of the Senior at this time. Try as he might
to exclude them, little twinges of regret are bound to appear, regret
that he is soon to sever connections with the Johns Hopkin4 undergraduate body; regret that the scenes of many happy moments are to
be left behind; regret that many familiar and well-liked faces are
to be seen in the future only at widespread and infrequent intervals.
Rejoicing, perhaps, predominates, but it is unmistakably intermingled
with a certain amount of sadness.
Nor do the Seniors hold a monopoly upon this latter feeling. The
undergraduate body is confronted with a most unpleasant task when
it is compelled to say "good-bye" to the members of the Class of 1923.
In their four years of residence this class and its members have succeeded in binding themselves firmly to the University, its ideals and
its activities, and it is difficult and painful to imagine Johns Hopkins
without them.
As we have said, however, Commencement Time should be a
period of rejoicing; regrets should be pushed into the background.
We have been trying to say "good-bye" to the members of the Class
of 1923 and to tell them th'at we shall miss them. Our efforts, although feeble, are sincere.
There are but two things remaining for us to say. The first is
to ask that the Class of 1923 keep in close touch with undergraduate
affairs and endeavor to form an active alumni body, devoted to the
interests of the University. Our second duty, or may it be called a
privilege, is to wish the members of the graduating class "Godspeed."
We do!

A NEW ERA
This issue of the News-Letter marks the close of the collegiate
year 1922-23, the forty-sixth year of the University's existence. In
this period Johns Hopkins has gone through two eras: the first, from
the University's founding to its removal to the Homewood site; the
second, lasting from tile time of this removal to the present day.
Next year, with the dormitories an established fact and with an
elaborate programme of expansion, Hopkins enters upon the third
era of its existence. It will be a critical period for the undergraduate
school. Whether the world at large will continue to regard Johns
Hopkins as only a Medical School or whether the influence of the
undergraduate school will be extended, will be decided in the near
future.
The result is dependent for a large part upon the undergraduate
body.

COACH SCHMEISSER

COACH SCHMEISSER PAYS GLOWING TRIBUTE TO
HOPKINS LACROSSE TEAM
The Team of 1923 is the best Lacrosse Team Hopkins has ever
turned out. I say this after careful consideration, having studied my
records, seen the teams of the last twenty-four years in action and
known the players all personally. Further I have talked to the important players of four more years before that and followed the best
of them in uniform. Previous to twenty-eight years ago the game
was different.
The 1923 aggregation has more fine players on it than any previous twelve. The team is remarkably well balanced. Every man
from in home to second defense inclusive can shoot goals and has
done it. Every attack-man and part of the defense is always a scoring threat. Six out of the eight attack men are finished dodgers.
Four out of eight attack-men can shoot from both sides. The midfield, the heart of any great Lacrosse Team is very effective; two are
long distance men, the other four fast on the sprint.
The defense consists of nine well balanced players. An aggressive defense not a conservative one. The proper balance of speed
and weight and good stickhandlers for close work.
There is no weak spot in the whole team. It is full of harmony,
punch, intelligence, resourcefulness and teamwork. Further it still
has undeveloped power which will never be utilized as it is shortly
to go the way of all good college teams into the real of found remembrance.
(Signed) WM. C. SCHMEISSER,
Johns Hopkins Lacrosse Team

Hopkins News-Letter

We Echo
Patrick Henry!

Liberty
H AT

But the man who is particular about style will be
just as insistant as Patrick Henry about getting
the Liberty, — it's a hat
that stands for correctness in style and the utmost in value.

Hilarity and self-satisfaction, however, are not the only elements
to enter into the mind of the Senior at this time. Try as he might
to exclude them, little twinges of regret are bound to appear, regret
that he is soon to sever connections with the Johns Hopkin4 undergraduate body; regret that the scenes of many happy moments are to
be left behind; regret that many familiar and well-liked faces are
to be seen in the future only at widespread and infrequent intervals.
Rejoicing, perhaps, predominates, but it is unmistakably intermingled
with a certain amount of sadness.
Nor do the Seniors hold a monopoly upon this latter feeling. The
undergraduate body is confronted with a most unpleasant task when
it is compelled to say "good-bye" to the members of the Class of 1923.
In their four years of residence this class and its members have succeeded in binding themselves firmly to the University, its ideals and
its activities, and it is difficult and painful to imagine Johns Hopkins
without them.
As we have said, however, Commencement Time should be a
period of rejoicing; regrets should be pushed into the background.
We have been trying to say "good-bye" to the members of the Class
of 1923 and to tell them th'at we shall miss them. Our efforts, although feeble, are sincere.
There are but two things remaining for us to say. The first is
to ask that the Class of 1923 keep in close touch with undergraduate
affairs and endeavor to form an active alumni body, devoted to the
interests of the University. Our second duty, or may it be called a
privilege, is to wish the members of the graduating class "Godspeed."
We do!

A NEW ERA
This issue of the News-Letter marks the close of the collegiate
year 1922-23, the forty-sixth year of the University's existence. In
this period Johns Hopkins has gone through two eras: the first, from
the University's founding to its removal to the Homewood site; the
second, lasting from tile time of this removal to the present day.
Next year, with the dormitories an established fact and with an
elaborate programme of expansion, Hopkins enters upon the third
era of its existence. It will be a critical period for the undergraduate
school. Whether the world at large will continue to regard Johns
Hopkins as only a Medical School or whether the influence of the
undergraduate school will be extended, will be decided in the near
future.
The result is dependent for a large part upon the undergraduate
body.

COACH SCHMEISSER

COACH SCHMEISSER PAYS GLOWING TRIBUTE TO
HOPKINS LACROSSE TEAM
The Team of 1923 is the best Lacrosse Team Hopkins has ever
turned out. I say this after careful consideration, having studied my
records, seen the teams of the last twenty-four years in action and
known the players all personally. Further I have talked to the important players of four more years before that and followed the best
of them in uniform. Previous to twenty-eight years ago the game
was different.
The 1923 aggregation has more fine players on it than any previous twelve. The team is remarkably well balanced. Every man
from in home to second defense inclusive can shoot goals and has
done it. Every attack-man and part of the defense is always a scoring threat. Six out of the eight attack men are finished dodgers.
Four out of eight attack-men can shoot from both sides. The midfield, the heart of any great Lacrosse Team is very effective; two are
long distance men, the other four fast on the sprint.
The defense consists of nine well balanced players. An aggressive defense not a conservative one. The proper balance of speed
and weight and good stickhandlers for close work.
There is no weak spot in the whole team. It is full of harmony,
punch, intelligence, resourcefulness and teamwork. Further it still
has undeveloped power which will never be utilized as it is shortly
to go the way of all good college teams into the real of found remembrance.
(Signed) WM. C. SCHMEISSER,
Johns Hopkins Lacrosse Team
